Understate: The claim understates the fact that President Trump's proclamation does not establish a permanent new name for the observance.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by suggesting that President Trump was the first president to apply the term "African-American History Month," when in fact previous presidents have used similar terminology.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to suggest that President Trump changed the name of Black History Month to African-American History Month.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider the alternative explanation that President Trump's use of the term "African-American History Month" was not a permanent renaming but rather a variation of the existing terminology.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that President Trump's proclamation did not establish a permanent new name for the observance, as other presidents have used similar terminology in their proclamations.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of President Trump's use of the term "African-American History Month" by suggesting that he renamed the observance, when in fact the terms "Black History Month" and "African-American History Month" have been nearly interchangeable since President Gerald Ford issued the first proclamation.
